text:
Hey <@U04J7TVCQGP>, I hope everything's going great on your end! I thought it'd be helpful to organize my thoughts and ask you some questions via Slack. So here goes.

Updates so far:
• Breaking ground on Fastify API development- it's my first time developing with a "local-first" rather than "cloud-first" mentality, but I think we've got a good solution in place.
• I registered <http://equalify.dev|equalify.dev> to simplify all of my AWS work and give us a non-production domain to work with. Here are some resources/endpoints I've provisioned:
    ◦ Route 53
        ▪︎ Just an easy DNS service that plugs into AWS services ($0.50/mo for <http://equalify.dev|equalify.dev>)
    ◦ EC2
        ▪︎ These have t4g.micro EC2 instances under the hood with an Elastic IP routed through Cloudfront ($11/mo each)
        ▪︎ <https://graphql.equalify.dev> - Production GraphQL engine
            • Password: `Mryvn5h63PmkyfaroxsNzpy8Y7sYwvJmyeDmFi3J24XjDvhrXSMkK9R6amezZRamdyoCnpHR3Ln6tEMV3fJMs2GCrPxiA5pj23JtEoN6VmHCWPRDYwtkRPygrKU4bfZj`
        ▪︎ <https://graphql-staging.equalify.dev> - Staging GraphQL engine
            • Password: `TMTJcJoeuB65WFi8XE5JBr2F4cEANuMws5CVS473JXDKuSsHRiT3KqYepjQttAve9LK3K9rgnn6SwTyZ7uAqosESgVozAvqmk2xfdyfkVueSDV7MRCCBhYW2LrnmrTYT`
        ▪︎ <https://db.equalify.dev> - Cloudbeaver DB Viewer (think PhpMyAdmin, but for the modern age)
            • Username: `equalify`
            • Password: `Equalify2024!`
    ◦ Lambda
        ▪︎ These are Node.js Lambda functions with Function URLs routed through Cloudfront ($0/mo)
        ▪︎ <https://api.equalify.dev> - Production Lambda API
        ▪︎ <https://api-staging.equalify.dev> - Staging Lambda API
    ◦ Relational Database Service
        ▪︎ I provisioned 2 t4g.micro PostgreSQL databases ($13/mo each)
        ▪︎ <http://equalify.c3mkya8ai9xe.us-east-2.rds.amazonaws.com|equalify.c3mkya8ai9xe.us-east-2.rds.amazonaws.com> - Production PostgreSQL DB
            • Host: `<http://equalify.c3mkya8ai9xe.us-east-2.rds.amazonaws.com|equalify.c3mkya8ai9xe.us-east-2.rds.amazonaws.com>`
            • Username: `equalify`
            • Database: `equalify`
            • Password: `Mryvn5h63PmkyfaroxsNzpy8Y7sYwvJmyeDmFi3J24XjDvhrXSMkK9R6amezZRamdyoCnpHR3Ln6tEMV3fJMs2GCrPxiA5pj23JtEoN6VmHCWPRDYwtkRPygrKU4bfZj`
            • Port: `5432`
        ▪︎ <http://equalify-staging.c3mkya8ai9xe.us-east-2.rds.amazonaws.com|equalify-staging.c3mkya8ai9xe.us-east-2.rds.amazonaws.com> - Staging PostgreSQL DB
            • Host: `<http://equalify-staging.c3mkya8ai9xe.us-east-2.rds.amazonaws.com|equalify-staging.c3mkya8ai9xe.us-east-2.rds.amazonaws.com>`
            • Username: `equalify`
            • Database: `equalify`
            • Password: `TMTJcJoeuB65WFi8XE5JBr2F4cEANuMws5CVS473JXDKuSsHRiT3KqYepjQttAve9LK3K9rgnn6SwTyZ7uAqosESgVozAvqmk2xfdyfkVueSDV7MRCCBhYW2LrnmrTYT`
            • Port: `5432`
    ◦ Cloudfront
        ▪︎ I created proxies for all of the above services so they could be served through easy endpoints from `*.<http://equalify.dev|equalify.dev>` (and also protected by AWS WAF w/ rate limiting)
    ◦ Bedrock
        ▪︎ Applied for access to all LLM models (Claude, Mistral, etc)
I had a few questions:
• Would you be comfortable migrating from MySQL to PostgreSQL?
    ◦ PostgreSQL would allow us to use fancy extensions like `pgVector` which let us store & index vector embeddings (very helpful for RAG integrations w/ LLMs, super efficient search, etc).
    ◦ I could leverage my experience w/ either the <https://github.com/hasura/graphql-engine|Hasura> or <https://www.graphile.org/postgraphile/|Postgraphile >GraphQL engines, which would help create a CRUD API and simultaneously enforce authorization rules out-of-the-box using JWT tokens from Auth0. We'd still have a Node.js API with business logic, but we could pass through "dumb" queries to these engines
• Would you be comfortable with switching from a "database per user" approach to a "single database" approach? We'd match users' resources using a `user_id` UUID column.
• Have you applied for AWS Activate credits before?
• I could not log into the Auth0 account because I was asked for an MFA code sent to your number. Perhaps you could add me to the Auth0 team as an admin?
• Would you consider migrating from Auth0 to AWS Cognito for auth? I'm personally more familiar with AWS Cognito (and it's got a much cheaper MAU rate than Auth0), but Auth0 has better documentation/redundancy
• Could you enable <https://us-east-1.console.aws.amazon.com/billing/home?region=us-east-1#/account|IAM user and role access to Billing Information>? I attached a screenshot of where the toggle is, only the account owner can flip it. It'd help give me insight into cloud costs.
And closing thoughts:
• I looked at the frontend channel and thought I could lend my hand in scaffolding a simple React app as a single page application with Vite- you can see the message I left there.

text: AMAZING! I’ll respond to your questions in different message so we can start threads if need be:

elements.text: AMAZING! I’ll respond to your questions in different message so we can start threads if need be:

text: • PostgreSQL is the way to go!

elements.text: PostgreSQL is the way to go!

text: • Never applied AWS Activate credits to that account.

elements.text: Never applied AWS Activate credits to that account.

text: • Auth0 recovery code is `959Q8PBYG8YMLTM6UBE7B32G`. We’re trying to avoid their $35/mo fee because we really don’t need the features they have.

elements.text: . We’re trying to avoid their $35/mo fee because we really don’t need the features they have.

text: • Please migrate from Auth0. I’m not a fan of Auth0

text: Very happy to hear about the greenlight for Cognito... their service is honestly awesome even though many people on the internet complain about it

text: Totally! This project is built off whatever tech contributors are enthusiastic about.
